catch up.translation[0].definitions[0].d: to improve and reach the same standard as other people in your class, group etc
catch up.translation[0].definitions[0].e: If you miss a lot of classes, it’s very difficult to catch up.
At the moment our technology is more advanced, but other countries are catching up with us.
catch up.translation[0].definitions[1].d: to come from behind and reach someone in front of you by going faster
catch up.translation[0].definitions[1].e: Drive faster – they’re catching up with us.
You go on ahead. I’ll catch you up in a minute.
catch up.translation[0].definitions[2].d: to do what needs to be done because you have not been able to do it until now
catch up.translation[0].definitions[2].e: I have some work to catch up on.
I need to catch up on some sleep (=after a period without enough sleep).
catch up.translation[0].definitions[3].d: to spend time finding out what has been happening while you have been away or during the time you have not seen someone
catch up.translation[0].definitions[3].e: I’ll leave you two alone – I’m sure you’ve got a lot of catching up to do.
When I got home I phoned Jo to catch up on all the gossip.
catch up.translation[0].definitions[4].d: to be or get involved in something, especially something bad
catch up.translation[0].definitions[4].e: I didn’t want to get caught up in endless petty arguments.
